subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... I m glad you agree.  Of course there will continue to be discrepancies like Pea-Ah-Thaw vs. Pea-At-Thaw, which represent genuinely different phonemes
messageBody:
paulhtremblay scripsit:

> No its not. I actually agree with you that having a standardized
> spelling would make reading much easier. In fact, it may be essential
> to have standradized, or fairly standardized spelling.

I'm glad you agree. Of course there will continue to be discrepancies
like Pea-Ah-Thaw vs. Pea-At-Thaw, which represent genuinely different
phonemes rather than systematic changes in the sound representation
of the shared phonemes.

> If you read my posts, I have stated several times that QS either must
> have standardized spelling or be able to be mapped to the IPA.

Well, I think I've demonstrated that mapping letters to particular sounds,
the same sounds everywhere, doesn't work: we get severe misreadings.
If we don't try to do that, but map letters to phonemes using example
words, then, we can get spelling that is mostly standardized, with
some problems due to phonemic mergers. We may have to get used to
some people writing See-Ah-Tea where most people write See-I-Tea, or
even Fee-I-They-Utter-Roe instead of Fee-Ah-They-Utter-Roe, due to the
Southern American merger of these sounds.

The only way to get fully standardized spellings is to insist that
everybody learn by rote which words get Awe/Ox/Ah, which get I/Ah, and
so on. As it is, all the people who use non-rhotic dialects are already
going to have to learn by rote where to write Roe and where not to,
and many of them will get it wrong, writing I-Day-Eat-Utter with a Roe
at the end because that's the way they say it when the next word begins
with a vowel. (JFK was famous for this, and it's practically standard
in the South of England.) This seems to be what the Shavian community
does; in order to write Shavian correctly, you have to learn the
phonemic distinctions of RP.

> And if you think that I am just making up a hypothecial situation,
> thinking that no one could ever confuse /i/ with /I/ from the manual,
> I am looking at page 2 right now, which gives an example of #22 as in
> the word "busy," underlining both the "u" in the word and the "y." But
> the final "y" has a /i/ sound, not /I/!

It does now for most people. But in Read's day, /I/ was the preferred
sound, and /i/ was either lower-class or American. Some Americans,
for that matter, still have /I/: Jimmy Carter pronounces his name
Jay-It-May-It, with the two syllables rhyming perfectly.

Fortunately, it makes no great difference which one you use, because
although /I/ and /i/ contrast when stressed, when unstressed the
distinction is neutralized, just as it is before "ng" -- there are no
minimal pairs. Read is merely suggesting standardizing on It because
that was the more prestigious pronunciation at the time.

> In fact, I read a book on writing systems a few years ago that suggested
> that TO was actually a pretty good system for writing English precisely
> because of its extra letters, which makes site reading easier.

("Sight reading"; an excellent example of a useless TO distinction!)
I posted on this yesterday: TO is sort of cross-dialectal, but the cost
is still much higher than it should be. We could make modest changes
to TO that got rid of a lot of its problems without going all the way
to phonemic (still less phonetic) orthography and a whole new script,
for that matter.

> While these letters may be easy to write, I wonder if
> they make QS impractical for publishing books (if it should ever get
> to that stage!)--or will more practice prove that these letters are
> not a problem?

Historically, TO arose because printers wanted agreement on a standardized
orthography.

--
